editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Counterfeit Bridegroom: OR THE Defeated Widow. A COMEDY, As it is Acted at His Royal Highneſs THE Duke's Theatre.
LONDON, Printed for Langley Curtiſs in Goat-Court upon Ludgate-Hill, 1677.

div.head: PROLOGUE
div.l: WHo have we here, ſine Sparks, faith Sirs I fear
You'l not be pleas'd with our Vacation Chear;
Why, what a Devil make you now in Town
I'th' Mall, the Park, and Play-houſe Cloaths were ſhown,
Down, down to th' Countrey, there ſhow the Gay Baboon;
Cloris, and Celia do expect ye there,
To th' honeſt Tradeſmen leave this time o'th' year,
Who, (while their Wives (good men) are gone to meet
Some of you Sirs t'th' Countrey here can ſit
Wonderouſly pleas'd with our Vacation Treat.
But ſince againſt the Rules of Gallantry
Ye keep in Town, faith take your Chance for me;
Huff, Damn and Swear, if you think good—but then
Expect a bruſh fro'th' Trading Gentlemen,
For' tis their time t' approve or to Condemn:
You'l ſay, 'tis hard, you cannot be allow'd
To Judg, and cenſure with the Common Crowd;
Nay to be bar'd from damning, ſwearing too,
When, here, you've hardly little elſe to do,
Since Vizards are grown ſcarce:—might I adviſe,
If you will come, let 't be in ſome diſguiſe,
With Coat, Short wig, and Colbertein Crevat,
With greaſy Gloves, and the broad flapping hat,
Then freely ye may give the Play its Fate;
But if you boldly will Uſurp their Right,
And huffing damn the Play out of meer ſpight,
'Cauſe it affords not you deboacht delight,
You juſtly may expect that They will ſwear
Vacation Pocket 'tis, that keeps you here;
And Play at Half a Crown does now prove Dear.

list.item: Sir Oliver Santloe—Mr. By A. Leigh.
Mr. Noble—Brother to Mrs. Hadland. Mr. Croſby.
Mr. Gazer—An Aſtrological old Fool—Mr. Norris.
Mr. Noddy—A Country Squire—Mr. John Lee.

body.head: THE Counterfeit Bridegroom: OR THE Defeated Widow.

div.head: Act the Firſt. Scene the Firſt.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: I Am at my Wits ends, Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Faith Sir, like a kind Friend, I'm following you as faſt as I can.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: My Wife will be forc't from me, my pleaſure, my delight.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How ſhall we help it, Sir, dull, dull dogg as I am, my invention was never ſo gravell'd ſince I firſt ſet out upon't.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: But this is not all my miſery—for I am branded with the breach of Friendſhip: for Sanders do's ſuſpect that I make Love to his Miſtreſs the Widows Neece Eugenia; when Heav'n knowes, 'tis my Father that works againſt the peace of both our ſpirits, and courts her for me.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Let him go on, Sir, She'l hardly yield to an Old Man's Courtſhips, eſpecially when ſhe finds you appear not in it— but Sir, here's Mr. Sanders with looks as melancholy and angry as a Looſeing Bulley of Marribone.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: My treacherous Rival there! draw Sir—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: What means my Friend?—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Not a word, but defend thy life.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: I'le dye before I'll draw againſt the man that I love; what reaſon?—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Thy Perjuries have blotted out the name of Friend, and out of Cowardiſe you endeavour to excuſe an act, not Heav'n it ſelf can pardon, much leſs I,—but thus I will repay thy falſhood.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir,—here's like to be fine work— Pray hear him firſt before you kill him, Sir,—upon my life, your anger is in an Error all this while; for 'tis my young Maſters Injury and not yours, you would kill him for— Come Sir, I muſt have ye friends, a pox on weapons— Mr. Sanders your hand, Sir,— Now yours, Sir,—So, ſo— Now all's right again: This is a new way of reconciling Friends, which I learnt the other day among the Town Blades—

div.stage: Sam. takes Sanders by one hand, and P. S. by t'other, and ſhakes e'm.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Th'art a mad Slave.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Now Sam, tell him the Secret, which none knowes but your ſelf and I, and he will confeſs he has wrong'd the patience of his Friend.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Be patient then and attend—You muſt know, Sir, That about Seven Years ſince my Lady, his Mother, went over to Flanders, to coop the Young Chick his Siſter in a Nunnery, ſhe then being about Nine Years old; but on the Road to Antwerp, they met Thieves, were robb'd, ſtript, and parted; for the Kites convey'd the Young One-away, and left the Old one to cackle over her loſs.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Strange accident!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: From which time they were not heard off, till about Three Months ſince, News came of all had paſt, in a Letter from the Mother, who was then but in an ill condition at Colone; for thither ſhe had wandred to find out her Daughter, but deſpairing of that, ſhe ſent over for Money to bring her home with—My Old Maſter no ſooner heard of the Sum, but told it out, gave it him, and ſent us over; but we unfortunately calling at Antwerp by the way, a little Gypſie at an Inn, had ſo look't her ſelf into his heart, that the Mother was forgot, and he doated ſo, that he brought her over, and this day marry'd her; but pretends it is his Siſter; for which ſhe now paſſes with the Old Man.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: But how came you off concerning her Mother?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: With a Tale of my own deviſing, That about 3 Years ſince ſhe dyed at a little Village within Two Leagues of Antwerp.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Let me admire thee—and withal confeſs my groundleſs Jealouſie.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Which thus I pardon—and renew our former friendſhip—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: But here's the Devil on't, my Old Maſter concluding her his Daughter, has found out a Match for her, an Old Rank Fox, one Gazer.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: What he that woes by the Almanack? obſerves the Full and Change oth' Moon, and makes it his buſineſs to conform all his actions and deſigns to the Influence of the Planets?

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: The very ſame, he will not ſhave his Beard, clip his Nails, nor cut a Corn before he has conſulted Erra Pater, whether it be a lucky day or no.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Even he, becauſe the Fool demands no portion—but if my skill fail not, I ſhall give him the Go-by.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: As how, good Sam?

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Honeſt Rogue ſay how.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Thus—when the Fool's caſhier'd, as that he ſhall be, I'le tell my Old Maſter, that you admire his Daughter, and your Love's ſo great, that provided you might have her, you'd take her without a farthing—it's no ſooner heard, but the bait is ſwallow'd, you are admitted, and the Match concluded.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: But how will you ſhift off the Marriage?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I have a Trick for that too—and each ſhall have his own—and both being lodg'd in one houſe, as 'tis his pride to have his Childrens Children got ſucceſſively, on his fore-fathers Beds—in the Day time to pleaſe the Old Man, ye may dally and print a kiſs on the wrong Lip, and no harm in't; for Brothers and Siſters may do't: But for the Night, let each know his own buſineſs, and there I'le leave you.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Honeſt Rogue, how I applaud thy Witt.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: See, my Father's coming—let us retire—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: About it ſtraight, my Maſter's time is precious— and let me alone with my Old Maſter—

div.stage: Manet Sam. To him Sir Oliver Santlow.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: How now Sirrah, does the Love-buſineſs go well between the Young Ones?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Between your Son, and Mris. Eugenia the Line is Even, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: And ſhall I be a Grandſire then?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh queſtionleſs, Sir—but Sir methinks there's no proportion between that Equinoctial and my Young Miſtreſs Clarina.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: You mean Gazer: why the better Man; the better.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How Sir, are you glad there's no proportion in't?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Yes marry am I Sir; for I would have you to know, I hate all words that end in portion—for I'le give her nothing.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Say you ſhould not, Sir, as I'le ne're urge your Worſhip againſt your Nature—is there no Gentleman (think you) of Worth and Credit, that will not open his Bed to warm a plump, handſome, charming naked Lady? believe me, Sir, there are Thouſands in this Town wou'd be glad of ſuch Service; nay, and wou'd give Money rather then not be ſo employ'd.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Say you ſo? then they ſhall give me money for my Girl, or they ſhall go without her.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes, they do give, keep, and treat, but not marry Sir, which I ſuppoſe you are for.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: For quoth I? my Daughter ſhan't be a Whore, no not to get money, which is the beſt plea the Jades of the Town have for their lewdneſs, and in troth I love wealth ſo, that in my conſcience had I bin a Maid, I had turn'd Strumpet mearly for mony ſake.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A Smiting one 'yfaith—but Sir methinks there's a great inequality in years—Mr. Gazer is too old in conſcience for my young Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: You lye Sirrah—he is but fifty five years of diſcretion, and will make a Staid Husband.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: As tame as a Drone that has loſt his ſting—but Sir, under correction, I fear he is paſt getting of Children, which young Women love extreamly, and I ſhould be loath my young Miſtris ſhould lye fallow before ſhe has yielded fruit.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p:
Sarrah do not provoke me to wrath—not he get Children, when 'tis well known that a tough old Fox of Threeſcore
and Nine got a Girl of ten with Child—but however ſhould he prove impotent, it would be the better I ſay ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Would you not be a Grandfather by your Daughter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: No Sir—my Son will make me that, and ſhould my Daughter too, 'twould undoe me, double charges Sam. double charges.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Then I know a young Gentleman, between you and I Sir, as impotent as an Eunuch, that has all the paſſions of Love, but incapable of Action; beſides he has a great Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: How ſay you? a rich Eunuch? what a bleſſings that! and is he in Love with my Girl! bleſſing on bleſſing—name him, honeſt Varlet, who is it?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Mr. Sanders, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: How, Mr. Sanders?—why Sirrah, had not he laſt Seſſion a Baſtard laid to his Charge, for which he was fined twenty Pounds.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: True Sir, but 'twas his Footmans Baſtard, which he only Fathered, for his credit; the caſe of many Blades now a days to keep up reputation.

sp.speaker: Sir. O.
sp.p: But he 'l have a portion too.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: To my knowledge not, Sir; alas he has a vaſt Eſtate already, which he intends to ſettle on your Daughter, and then Sir when he dyes 'twill all come to your Family.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Art ſure of that?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: He told me ſo himſelf Sir, and ſaid likewiſe, he would leave all to your Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Nay then it's my own, and the Devil a penny he gets of me.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Sir ſhall I fetch him, ere it be too late; for he's ſo raving Mad, that ſhortly he'le either be in Bedlam, or break his neck off ſome Steeple.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Now bleſs the young mans griſtles, I ſhould be loath to looſe ſuch an Eſtate, and ſee a begging Courtier go away with what might have been mine—therefore prithee find him out that I may pronounce words of conſolation to him— before he be paſt all recovery; for I would not looſe the bleſſing of an Eunuch Husband for my Daughter, for the World—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: But Sir you'l ſend the Gull, the weathercock going Firſt?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
Sam.
sp.p: But Sir, take no notice for the World, that he is an Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Not a word, begon, begon man—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Let me ſee, let me ſee, what comfort gives my Almanack to day—

Luck I beſeech thee, good dayes evil dayes, June, July, Auguſt, ſpeak a word for me now, the Girl's my own; let me ſee the Eighth day between Hawk and Buzzard, (I remember I was drunk then) the Ninth day on a ſlippery pin, the Tenth day the Markets marr'd, the Eleventh day againſt the hare— againſt the hare! a pox on the hare, wou'd it had bin left out, had it been againſt any thing but the hare, I had not valued it— however I'le try the fortune of a good face, tho my Almanack leaves me in the Sudds.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Mr. Sanders and an Eunuch too!—well, 'tis a prodigious Match! nay I thought I ſhould have good luck to day, becauſe I riſe with my butt end formoſt this morning as they ſay.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Oh here's my Father-in-Law that muſt be, Sir Oliver your moſt dutiful Son-in-law and Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: An Eunuch! by Gogmagog he's happier then all the Whoring Gallants of the Town.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: How? an Eunuch! I ſcorn your words, Sir, 'tis well known I have three chopping Baſtards at Nurſe—but, Sir Oliver—Sir Oliver Santloe—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Moon-Calf, are you there? prithee depart, for I am very buſie at preſent—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: When ſhall I wait on you then, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Why, let me ſee, about a quarter of a year hence—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: A quarter of a year hence? what ſhall I come in September or October?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: No Sir, nor in November neither, good my Friend—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: You are not mad, Knight? you will not let your Daughter hang paſt Auguſt, will you? if Sir you do, ſhe'l ſoon drop under the Tree, for ſhe's no winter fruit I'le aſſure you—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: By Gog and Magog 'tis no matter for that, my daughter is not fruit for your tooth—therefore be not impertinent, but march off—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Your Promiſe is paſt—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: A fart for Promiſes—I tell you y'are troubleſome —what think you I'le marry my daughter to a Planter of the Skyes, pray what Settlement will you make, of the 12 Planets, and once a year they march out of your Lordſhip; I'le not beſtow my daughter on one who can make no Joynture, but of Caſtles in the Air—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: But I have an Eſtate—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: For ought I know 'tis one by Conjuration, and the Charm may be out if you dye, and when my Girl thinks ſhe's on ſubſtantial Land, may find her ſelf in the midſt of an Iriſh Bogg—in ſhort, Sir—you ſhall have none of my daughter—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Then may the Devil choak ye with Money, and may a Fidler run away with your daughter, not have your daughter? a Pox on your daughter. Adieu, Sir; now for my Widow, I'le never leave an open hearted Widow for a narrow ey'd Maid agen: go out of the Road-way like an Aſs to leap over Hedge and Ditch—I'le fall into the beaten Road agen, and invite the Widow home to a Banquet and make amends for my neglect of not waiting on her yeſterday—

lg.l: My Almanack told me true, how I ſhou'd fare:
Let no man think to ſpeed againſt the Hair.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: So, he's gone, may all the Stars by whatſoever Titles they are dignified and diſtinguiſht look a skew upon all his Enterpriſes—
Oh luckey Rogue, ha'ye brought Mr. Sanders—he looks ſo ſad, he grieves my very Soul, poor Fool—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Sir, there's the old Gudgeon, now catch him neatly and your buſineſs is done.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Sanders, what you are in love it ſeems; One might gueſs by your hanging look you are poſſeſt with that troubleſome ſpirit—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: I am ſo, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: For my daughter—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: True, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: And you'd kill your ſelf for her—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: My Life will be a burden if I have her not—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: In good time, Sir—but then you expect no Portion?

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Something by which you do acknowledge her your daughter, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Acknowledge her your daughter! what a wheedling Phraſe was that to get Money—but 'twont do—in a word, Sir, if you like, love, and will marry my Girl without a Portion ſo, if not—Lord have mercy upon you, and ſo go hang your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How dexterouſly he wheedles himſelf into the nooſe.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: But, Sir, if you'l beſtow no Portion, you'l give her Cloaths and Wedding-dinner—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Yes that I will, Sir, and more; you ſhall board in my Houſe gratis for three Years, if that will do: look out no further, for I'le reprieve you from your grinning deſtiny—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Then thus I joyfully return my acknowledgments for your kind compliance, and admire your judgment and diſcretion, for a Woman's Virtue is the richeſt Dower ſhe can poſſeſs—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Now I love thee for thy wiſdom, riſe, riſe, and a Bleſſing on you both—

div.p: How now Son, whither ſo faſt—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: To viſit my Miſtris, Mr. Sunſet's daughter, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: A good Boy—ply it hard both of ye; theſe young Sluts are as skittiſh as unbackt Colts—Do ye hear, agree't ſo ſoon as poſſible, and one day, one dinner ſhall ſerve for both.
How ſoon my Joyes for my Girles good Fortune have drown'd the Sorrow for my Wife's Loſs—well 'twas a good Soul —but why ſhould I grieve, ſince I enjoy her Picture in my daughter—
How now, the News with you, Sirrah—

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A Dutch Merchant, Sir, deſires to ſpeak with you—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: With me? what ſhou'd his buſineſs be tro—I have a Couſin in Holland, perhaps ſome News from him, the old buſineſs, ſome Firkins of Butter with Counterfeit Farthings, but tho the gain may be great, yet by Gog Magog I'le be no Trayter I, ſo I'le roundly tell him—

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Hadland with a Letter. Sir Gregory Lovemuch diſguis'd like a Porter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hadl.
sp.p: Well I muſt be reveng'd on this impertinent Leacher, he will not be repuls'd, yet in ſpight of poverty and all its curſt attendance of Calamities, I'le keep my Virtue ſtill, and my pretious Sir, the Goat, will appear under the Aſs's skin—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Thus far I am proſperous, Love, if it be thy will make her comply: Poverty! thou bleſt Bawd of Love, confute her ſullen Virtue, make her yield, and then I'm happy—
Now, Madam, what anſwer ſhall I give to the Worſhipful Knight that ſent me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I'le comply ſeemingly till I have an opportunity to be reveng'd for his unlawful Sollicitations.
Friend, you may tell Sir Gregory, That the ſmall Favour which in his Letter he requeſts was no ſooner read but granted—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Oh divine Beauty! let me embrace my Treaſure—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Sir Gregory Lovemuch in the Habit of a Porter, it amazes me.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Oh Madam, Love, Love has a thouſand ways to diſcover it ſelf and its Deity—and this was mine—ſpeak, Madam, and with the harmonious ſound make me all rapture, new create me Young, ſay, ſhall I enjoy that mighty Bleſſing I have ſo long toyl'd and labour'd for?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I will conſider further of it, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p:
Oh dally not with time, my fair, let us now improve
this bleſt time of your Husband's abſence—I met him at the Temple, I ſuppoſe—gone to his Lawyer's Chamber—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Very right Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Shall we, ſhall we withdraw then to your Chamber?— fair one?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: And wrong my Husband, and the Widow whom you are about to Marry? 'twoud be unkindly done of me—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: I marry her Wealth, not Perſon—when I've the Bleſſing of her Eſtate, it ſhall be at your Command, I marry her only to ſupply my Purſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs 'twill be a home revenge upon her, for ſhe now enjoys my Eſtate, which her Husband by Knaviſh practiſes, couzen'd my Father of juſt before he dyed—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: That's my deſign to force her make a reſtitution of your Eſtate; for all, all ſhe has you ſhall be ſole Commandreſs of—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Your Promiſes are great—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: The performance too ſhall be ſo, her golden ſhowers ſhall fall into your lap, and one kiſs ſhall ranſom ineſtimable Jewels from their impriſonment of her Cabinet; come, come, my ſweet, let me partake of the boundleſs bliſs of Love.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Let me a while conſider Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Time enough to conſider when we have taſted of Love's pleaſing banquet, and this minute loſt may be ominous for the future.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I ask but one days time, Sir Gregory then, let the reſt be yours.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Happy, happy I, 'tis granted Madam; one kiſs, my Dear, and then I'm gone—
Oh how divinely does ſhe kiſs!
So great a gift muſt be thus rewarded—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Within Wife, Sweet heart, where are you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Oh Heav'ns, Sir Gregory, my Husband! ſhould he find you here?—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Madam, the Devil can't know me in this diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p:
He's come as I cou'd wiſh—Sir Gregory, let me prevail with you to ſtep into my Cloſet; for ſhou'd he come
and ſee you here, I am ſo young a Sinner, my guilt wou'd quickly betray me.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Do with me what you pleaſe—I wiſh I were well off.—

div.stage: [She locks Sir G. into a Cloſet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Now, my Dear, what comfort does the Law afford, ſhall werecover our loſt Eſtate, or are we doom'd to eternal Poverty?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: 'Tis paſt retrieve, Sweet heart,—the Fox was too ſubtle for us; but I am reſolv'd to attempt ſomething ſhall either end my life, or redeem our Eſtate—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: 'Tis not thereabout yet, Husband, deſpair not, for I have thought upon a way which I am reſolv'd to proſecute, and if it take effect, ſay once a Woman's undertaking may proſper—and we may be ſaid to ſhare in wit, as well as in your ſorrows; but till that opportunity happens, I have a rare old Fool in Limbo, a precious vigorous Lover, of Threeſcore and odd, who thinks our low fortunes may make me ſtoop to his unlawful deſires—'tis Sir Gregory Lovemuch— ſee here what a precious bate his Traps are furniſh't with to catch diſtreſſed Virtue.—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: 'Tis a rich Ring—but where have you beſtow'd that lump of Leachery and Impotence?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: In my Cloſet,—he's diſguis'd like a Porter, do what you pleaſe with him—

div.stage: [Sir G. makes a noiſe within, crying out, ſcat, ſcat whore— within.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Hell and the Devil, out Cats, out.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: What's the matter with him—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: See if you pleaſe—

div.stage: [Gives him the Key, he opens the Dore—ſlipt aſide, Sir. G. runs out—a Cat is ſeen.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p:
Gad take me, Madam,—Is your Husband gone?— a confounded Spawn of the Devil has almoſt frighted me out of my wits; I wonder what makes people fond of Cats, when their young they are abſolute Succubuſſes, and Witches when old—your Tabby Satan, a Pox on her, has made me impotent with her looks, and I am at preſent perfectly bewitcht— but I ſhall return to morrow, ſweet, with
new joys and vigour, when theſe Charms are ended.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Provided my Cat be not in the way—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: True, Madam,—therefore pray let me prevail that Puſs and Husband may be decently removed, for the ſight of either will make my Ague fit return.—

div.stage: Enter Hadland, meets Sir Gregory going out.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Ha! her Husband, then world farewel, for now I ſhall be kill'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: How no Sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: A poor fellow, an't pleaſe you.—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Stay friend, I muſt ſpeak with you before you go.— Sweet heart—Ha, a Letter, from whence came this?—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Now welcom Death—he'll diſcover all—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Nay, prithee Husband reſtore my Letter agen, 'tis from our Couſin in the City—wou'd have me—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: How in a man's hand?—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: A Plague on it, that I cou'd not counterfeit a Womans hand—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: One of her Apprentices writ it for her—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Do not tell me Stories—I partly know the hand; therefore will read it.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: But there are ſome ſecrets in it which ſhe conjures me not to let any one ſee—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Yet her Apprentice might write 'em—Now I am reſolved to read it.—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Now I am paſt all hopes, I ſhall be kill'd for being my own Pimp—Pox on him, he's poor, conſequently deſperate, and undoubtedly he'l cut my Throat, that he may be hang'd, and be out of his miſery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: You ſee, Sir Gregory, what a misfortune your ſtay has brought upon us.—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Ay too late, I ſee Madam—were I well off of this buſineſs, the Devil ſhou'd have Married Wives for me; the very thoughts of their Husbands coming up, does in the midſt of Enjoyment pall the appetite ſo, that half the pleaſure's loſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p:
A ſecret indeed, which you of all the world ſhou'd have kept from me—Is this the fruits of your pretended
ſanctity? are all your admonitions of Patience come to this? muſt I be made the monſter to maintain your luſt, ungrateful, falſe Woman?—this now confirms what I too much have heard abroad, concerng you and Sir Gregory that Goat, but I ſhall ſpoil the Amore.—
sp.stage: [Sir G. L. endeavours to ſteal off.
sp.p: How now Rogue, whether ſo ſlyly—this too's the Bawd to that Sir Fiſty—but I'le reward you e're you go.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Upon my knees, I begg—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Riſe, not a word, out of my ſight, go—for fear my paſſion make me raſhly act what I may too late repent of—prepare for the Country to go to your Relations agen—for here, I Vow never to live longer with you,— out of my ſight—go—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Then ſhe's my own, I'le meet her at the Coach when ſhe is to go, take new Lodgings, and give her a falſe name, and the dear delights of the Town will eaſily prevail with her to ſtay and embrace my offer; beſides, 'tis the Common practice of divorc't Wives to have Gallants under their Husbands Noſes—ha ſhe's gone, I like not his ſtaying.—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Now Sir, for your reward, thus I make [Beats him. acknowledgment, for I can ne're expect to be out of your debt.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Hold, Sir hold, oh hold, what means your Worſhip—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: To pay you for your pains.—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: I was paid before I came Sir; there's Porter paid, writ on the Letter, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Now, Sirrah, take this and deliver it to that Dog of a Knight, or I'le cut your Throat—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Lord Sir, do you queſtion it Sir? I am an honourer of your Worſhips—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Tell him if he meets me not, he muſt expect to be poſted for a Coward—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Gad for give me a Challenge? very fine, what have I got, to day a dry baſting, and to morrow muſt be run through the Lungs—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Rogue do you grumble—take that to remember you to ſave your Wind-pipe—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Nouns, I'le do't, I'le do't Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Yes, with a good baſting, and a Challenge, which I'le undertake will keep him waking beyond the Cure of Opium for this Night—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Oh Siſter, curſed Luck—the Dice and Devil prove my Enemies, my laſt, laſt dear ſtake of ten Guinnies are flown—and now I begin to reflect on our laſt diſcourſe about the Widow, is your deſign perfect—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: It is—take no care, for I am reſolved to ſet all right,—and Brother, what I can ſpare, take and try once more, what kindneſs Fortune will ſhow—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Thanks kind Girl—but ſtill my mind runs on this damn'd Widow, no revenge, prithee conſider Girl,—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Leave that to my Care—for you are not like to know any thing, till I ſee I ſhall ſucceed—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Well, honeſt Soul, I leave it to thy management; but let each other exchange Prayers for our deſigns.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Now for my deſign, you'l be aſſiſting.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: I will—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: We'le about it then ſtraight—

lg.l: Wit now perform, what Juſtice could not do;
All ways are juſt, when we our Rights purſue.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.
div.stage: A Table. Houſe. Mr. Gazer, Widow, Mr. Noddy.

sp.speaker: Gazer.
sp.p: WElcom, welcom Widow, to a Batchelor's houſe here, a ſingle man I, but for two or three Maids that I keep.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Are you double with them ſometimes then, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: An exceeding good mourning Wit, by Capricorn—

sp.speaker: Mr. Nod.
sp.p: I proteſt Widow y'are a moſt intolerable profound witty Lady—and ſo I kiſs your paws—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Mr. Noddy.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to you for your Complement, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: A curſe on Hadland, I ſhall not forget him in haſt, [Shrugs. however I'm for the Widow, and will ſtrike up the Match the ſooner, that I may ſend into the Country for one of her Tenants Daughters—for I muſt have a bit of young fleſh.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Sir Gregory! You honour me—ſee our Miſtreſs, keep her Company, whilſt I ſtep aſide and look after affairs—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Your Servant Brother Rival—You ſee Widow, what power your beauty has to make Rivals Friends and embrace— as thus—Mr. Noddy, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Your Slaves ſlave, to the third and fourth Generation, Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir Gregory you were remiſs in your duty to day—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Your pardon, your pardon Widow—but when, when will the bleſt day arrive that I ſhall take poſſeſſion of my treaſure in thee, Widow?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: In a day or two I ſhall make my Choice Sir Gregory, and then?—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: And then to bed Widow, ha Lady bright!— this Noddy's a very Aſs, Gazer a Gull.—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A couple of Fops—but Sir Gregory!

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: I underſtand you, a kiſs for the Conceit ſake, Widow.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: A murrion on him, how my mouth waters—what a curſed thing is modeſty.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: If conceit will ſtrike the ſtroke, have at the Widows Plumb-tree, I'le put 'em all down for a Banquet, Widow, and Gentlemen, my Friends and Servants, I make you wait long here for a Batchelor's pitance—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh Sir, you are pleas'd to be modeſt—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: No by my troth Widow, you ſhall find me otherwiſe.

div.stage: Muſick plays ſoftly—Enter Tenants with a Banquet, Twelve Diſhes with ſix Men, being the Twelve Signs.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How's this? the Twelve Months for our Plates, and the Twelve Signs for our Treat,

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Theſe are the ſigns of my Love Widow—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am ſorry you ſhould be at ſuch Charges, Sir, to feaſt us a whole Month together—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Widow th'art welcome a month, a year, for ever to me—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What are thoſe brought in the Banquet?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: My Tenants they ſtand for Faſting dayes.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Or the weeks in Lent.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Y'are in the right, Sir Gregory, ſweet Widow take your place here at Aries, that's the head ſign; a Widow is the head till ſhe is married—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But married, what is ſhe then?—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: The middle, the middle Widow—Sir Gregory Lovemuch, pray ſit here at Taurus, they ſay y' are a good Town-Bull.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Spare your Friends, Sir—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Mr. Noddy don't fall back ſo—here's Gemini for you Sir; for you had two chopping Boyes by your laſt Wife—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: No harm in that, Sir, the Widow may like me the better—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But, Sir, methinks your Signs are not perfect, your Tenants would do well to help fill the Table—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: By th' Maſs it's true, Widow—Tenants for once ſit down with your Harts on; but ſpare the Meat I charge you, as you hope for new Leaſes, I muſt make my Signs draw out a month yet, with a bit every morning at breakfaſt, and at Full Moon with a whole one; that's reſtorative, ſit round, ſit round, and do not ſpeak good Tenants, You may be bold enough, ſo you eat but little: How like you this, Widow?—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It ſhowes well, Sir—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: By my troth, Widow, I'm ſick that day my Table's empty; I wiſh ſome Gheſt or other to fill that gapp there—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Indeed the Feet for want of covering may catch cold, and then the head will quickly feel it—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Why then you may draw up your Leggs and lye rounder together.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: In troth, Madam, my Neighbour's a Notable Wagg—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: His Witt encreaſes with his eating.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Hadland in Man's Cloaths, comes in ſinging. Mrs. Hadland diſguis'd like her Serving-man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your Servants.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Another Suitor? then Piſces will be covered.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Madam, youl'e pardon my Intruſion; I heard your mirth, and thought a ſober Gentleman might be admitted to partake—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: There needs no excuſe, Sir, and with that Gentleman's leave I intreat you to ſit and do as we do.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Young Gentleman pray ſit, Y'are heartily welcome by Ceres.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray make room for the Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Sit ſtill Tenants, I'le call in all your Old Leaſes, and wrack you elſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Sirrah, Take my Hat and Sword—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then Sir, you mean he ſhall ſit as he comes?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: I, and he were a Lord he ſhall not ſit above my Tenants, I'le not have two Lords to 'em; ſo I may look for my Rent in another man's breeches.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Gentlemen ſit ſtill, I'le diſturb no body, but here take my fortune—

div.stage: [Sits down at the lower end o'th Table:

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: If you love Fiſh, pray fall too, Sir; had you come ſooner, you might hapned among ſome of the Fleſh ſigns, but now they are all taken up; Virgo had bin a good Diſh for you, had not one of my Tenants bin ſomewhat too buſie with her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I'm extreamly pleas'd with my Fortune here, Sir, 'tis the conceited'ſt Banquet I ever met with—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: What ſay you to a bit of Taurus?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: The Bull's too rank for me—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Too rank, Sir? does it offend you?

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Forbear, or I ſhall ſtrike you as dumb as your watery Kindred—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: With your heels or horns?

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Perhaps with both—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: It muſt be when I am aſleep then.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: It's a brave Girle, and nobly managed.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Hold Gentlemen, for the ſake of Mankind let not the Planets fall out; for if they deſtroy one another, what a world of abortive births, we ſhall have—Sirrah, run and fetch my Sun Cupp, his Beams ſhall diſperſe theſe clouds of Contention.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir, I make it my requeſt to you, to ſit—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Madam, you are obey'd—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Each look I take encreaſes my deſires, ſuch charms I never ſaw before; and ſhou'd he not be a Servant, my hopes will be all defeated.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: How is't Widow? Gentlemen chear up, fair weather in all Quarters; the Sun will riſe anon, I've ſent for him— Oh here he comes—Sing ſirrah, ſing the Song I gave you.

div.stage: Enter a Servant with a great Cup like the Sun.

lg.l: COme fill to the brim, for the Sun does go round,
And viſits the World in a day;
Our glaſs is our Sun,
Through our World he does run,
And each little drop is a Ray.
As the Sun with his Rayes does ripen the Earth,
And guild all the World with his Light;
So powerful Wine
Our Witts does refine,
And ripens our Joyes to delight.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Now fill it to the Widow—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What's here a Sun?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: It does betoken, Madam, a chearful day to ſome body.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my Service to ye all; for ye know the Sun muſt go through the Twelve Signs—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Moſt witty Widow, you jump with my Conceit; there's not a hair between us.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Give it Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: I am the next through whom the Golden flame muſt ſhine, the poor Feet there muſt wait and cool a while.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: My time will come, Sir—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: So round it goes— Fill it him again, Sirrah—

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Fill't me? why I drank laſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: I know you did, but Gemini muſt drink twice, unleſs you mean that one of 'em ſhould be choak't.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Well Mr. Gazer, y'are a merry Man—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fly from my heart all variable thoughts; ſhe that's entic'd by every pleaſing object, ſhall find ſmall Pleaſure, and as little Reſt— [Aſide. Sir Gregory Lovemuch—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: With your pardon, Madam, is this Sir Gregory, Lovemuch?

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: I am, Sir, I dare own my name—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: There's a rank Villain bears that name; are you of that Family, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Nay Sir, by Heav'n ſtit ſtill—leave roaring, I intend anon to bait you—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Yet agen? if you love me Gentlemen, let's have no roaring here—If I had thought of this, I'd have ſent my Bull to the Bear-Garden.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Sirrah, commend my Love and Service to the Widow, deſire her Ladiſhip to taſte that Morſel—

div.stage: Layes Sir G. L. Letter on a Trencher, and Mrs. H. carries it to the Widow.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: This is the Bitt I watch't for all this while.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: And wherein has this name of mine offended, that you are ſo liberal of your infamous Titles? I am a ſtranger to thee, but it muſt be known Sir, e're we two part—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: And good reaſon Sir—I don't intend to end ſo calmly with you; for my pretious Sir, I deſign to cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh ſtrike me dead! what's here—this ſhould be your hand, Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Undoubtedly, 'tis one of the Letters I ſent to you, Widow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Much good may do ye Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Niggers, noggers, what ailes the Widow—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: The Widow paints White, ſome Aqua Coeleſtis there, quickly—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh Treachery unmatch't, unheard of Villany!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: How do you, Madam?—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
O impudence! does my Diſeaſe ask how I do? can it
torment my heart, and look with a freſh colour in my face?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: What means the Widow?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: What qualm is this, Madam? I hope my Ram does not ſtick in your ſtomach.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
No, but an Old Leacherous Goat, a falſe Villain does— He that wou'd know a Villain when he meets him, let him look here; Here is a Glaſs will reflect his perfect Character— Oh thou preſerver of my ſtate, pray tell me, Sir, [To Mrs. Low.
that I may pay you all my Thanks together, what bleſſed accident brought that Letter to your hand, which has been long kept ſecret from me in my Enemies power?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Pleaſe you to retire, Madam, I ſhall unfold this Riddle—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Thou Baſilisk to Virtue out of my ſight, and ne're come near me more—Gentlemen pray come in and partake of a Story which may prove beneficial to you—

sp.speaker: Gaz. and Nod.
sp.p: We follow, Madam—

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Niggars, Sir, why don't you budge?—s'heart thruſt him out.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Out of my dores thou treacherous Fox—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: All Curſes ſcatter you—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Do you thunder? if you had ſtaid I'd have made bold to have ript out ſome of my Bull out of your belly again—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Now for the Widow, ſince the Knight's remov'd, I am reſolv'd to get drunk, infuſe confidence, be very rude, and then they ſay a Widow will yield.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Come, Brother Rival, let us to the Widow, and learn of her what Treachery this is—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Thus far my Wifes deſigns are ſucceſsful; now to my Charge, I muſt find out her Brother, and bring him hither to my Wife; what ſhe intends I know not.

div.head: SCENE the Second.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: My deſigns work rarely! well, if I go on and proſper, my Statute, when I dye, ſhall be ſet up in Braſs with an Inſcription, Here lyes the Machiavel of Love Intreigues—The two Young Blades are cloſe at it on a wrong ſcent, whilſt the Old Men are ready to diſſolve with joy.

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliver with a Dutch Boy.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Oh come, come, are you there, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Life! what's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: There's a new Reckoning come in ſince I ſaw you laſt.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Pox on't, I thought all had bin paid, I hate after-reckonings.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Pray come near Sir, let's be acquainted with you—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: You honour me too much, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Sirrah, Y'are impudence is great, nay you have bin bold enough too with my purſe abroad, if I am rightly inform'd; by Gogmagog if it be true, I'le have thee hang'd, drawn and quarter'd.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Who, I bold with your purſe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Yes you Sirrah—did not you bring me word about Ten Weeks ſince, my Wife was dead?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes, true Sir, very true Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Pray ſtay, Sawce-box, and hear me out; and did not you likewiſe ſay, That with the Money I ſent to defray my Wifes Charges, ſhe being, as you did aver, dead, you brought home my Daughter, whom by accident you met with at Antwerp?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Right as can be, Sir, I never found your Worſhip in a falſe Tale yet.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: I thank you for your good word, Sir; but I'm like to find your Worſhip in two at once.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I ſhould be ſorry to hear that, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: I believe you Sir—within this month my Wife was alive (which a Dutch Merchant, Father to this Boy who was juſt now with me, will juſtifie), ſo there's ſix Weeks of your Ten abated.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Strange! how men are grown to lying; that it is falſe, I'le juſtifie it with my life, Sir: I'm ſure, poor Lady, I dropt a Tear over her Grave; ſo did my Young Maſter too— if this Merchant were here, I'de tell him to his face that he wears a double Tongue; that is, Dutch and Engliſh—will the Boy ſay it, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Yes that he would, could you underſtand him; for he ſpeaks nothing but Dutch.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: All the better, I'le gabble ſomething to him— [Aſide Hoiſte kaloiſte kalooskin ſe vou, Dar Zun alla gaskin?

sp.speaker: D. Boy.
sp.p: Ick wet neat watt bey zackt, Ick vnverſton ewe neat.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I thought as much—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: What ſayes the Boy?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: He ſayes his Father is troubled with an imperfection at one time of the Moon—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Does the Boy ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I knew there was ſomething in't—your Wife alive! will you believe all Tales, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: But Sir he told me he ſaw this Wench you brought home, at Antwerp in an Inn: he tells me I am plainly couſened, and that ſhe's not my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: All's diſcovered—how Sir, not your Daughter? I muſt to't again.

div.p: Quisquivikin Sadlamara alla piſskickin ſows clows, hoff tofte le cumberſhaw, bouns buſs boxſeeno.

sp.speaker: D. Boy.
sp.p: Ick an ſawth no int hein clappon de heeke, I dinke vte zein zennon.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh ho! zein zennon! I thought I ſhould find it out at haſt; The Boy ſayes they never came near Antwerp, but a quite contrary way, round about by—Parnia.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: What means he by Zein Zennon, Sam?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p:
That is, he ſaw no ſuch Wench in an Inn; 'tis well I came ſo opportunely to get it out of the Boy before his Father
comes: pray be wary Sir, the World is ſubtle, come and pretend a charitable buſineſs, meerly to work out a piece of mony on you.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Maſs art advis'd of that?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The Age is cunning, Sir; beſides, a Dutchman will live upon any ground, and work Butter out of a Thiſtle.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Troth thou ſayes true in that; they're the beſt thrivers in Turneps, Cabidges, and Hartichokes, our Engliſh are not like 'em.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh fye Sir, whe the Treat that a States-man of Holland gives, would either choak or ſtarve an Engliſh man, dryed Stock-fiſh, pickled Herring, or the like, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Sam. ask him from whence they came when they came hither.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: That I will, Sir—Culluaron lagooſo, lageen, lagan, rufft, punkatee.

sp.speaker: D. Boy.
sp.p: Nime aweigh de cack.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What, what? I cannot blame him then.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: What ſays he to thee?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The poor Boy bluſhes for him, he tells me his Father came from making merry with certain of his Countrey-men, and he's a little ſteept in Engliſh Beer; there's no heed to be taken of his Tongue now.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Why this is ſtrange, how cameſt thou by all this? the Devil take me if I heard him ſpeak above three words to you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh Sir, the Dutch is a very wide Language, you ſhall have Ten Engliſh words go to the Explaining of one Dutch— As for example, Gulldergooſe—there's a word for you, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Why what is that ſame—Gull—Gull—Gulldergooſe, ha?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The Engliſh is—How do you and all your Generation?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Why 'tis impoſſible, 'tis impoſſible, man—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Thus I prove it by the Explanation, Sir,—Gull—how do you? der, and; Gooſe,—your Generation.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Methinks the Language is a little ſawcey—Gooſe, my generation—quoth a? but ſirrah, how came you to underſtand Dutch ſo well?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: By going to fetch home my Young Miſtreſs, Sir, we had in our Company a Young Frokin, who taught us it in a trice, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: What in a moneths time?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I'le undertake, Sir, in a Fortnights time you ſhall ſpeak as good Dutch as any Native of Holland, if you would learn, Sir—I ſhall be tript anon—pox on't wou'd I were fairly off—

div.p: Ile go ſeek out your Son, Sir; You ſhall hear what Thunder he'le bring with him—

sp.speaker: Sir. O.
sp.p: Do ſo, for I le have ye all face to face—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Cuds me what Elſe, Sir,—If you take me ſo near the Net agen, I le give you leave to wring my Neck off— I am come off fairly: We are undone in Dutch, all our Three months Rognery is come over in a Butter-Firkin.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: By Gogmagog an intricate bus'neſs this; I am ſo loſt between two Tales, I know not which to truſt,—The Boy is the likelieſt to tell truth; for he is not yet old enough to underſtand iniquity—but then why ſhould the Father tell me a lie, he gets nothing, certainly expects nothing; but by my troth if he does expect, he gets nothing of me, and ſo much good may it do him—but however, I'le in and examine the buſineſs further—

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I Have ſent in to the Widow—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Thou plyeſt thy buſineſs cloſe—the Coaſt is clear yet—that was a good ſurpriſe you put upon Sir Gregory—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I found him the ſenſibleſt Fool of the three to whom the Widow was inclin'd; therefore ought to be remov'd— be ſure, Husband, to ſtand Sentinel, and let me have warning when they come, and I'le rout 'em all—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: I'm gone my Witty Sweet—

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: My Lady, Sir, begs your pardon for making you wait, and ſhe will be with you ſo ſoon as ſhe has diſpatcht ſome of her Tenants come from Kent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Thank you Sir, 'tis fit I ſhould attend her leiſure.

Thoſe were my Tenants once, but what relief now; yet e're we part, Widow, I ſhall have full revenge—Your heart is mine already, and when the whole Cargoe's in my power, I'le hoiſt my ſailes, and with my ſtreams playing in the Aire, make to the bleſt Harbour of repoſe—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Wife, the pair of Fools are come juſt now lighted out of the Coach,—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Now to your duty—for I ſhall deal a little roughly with you, but you muſt not take it ill; for my obedience is in my Pettycoat Pocket, and not about me at preſent.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Uſe me as you pleaſe—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I hear 'em coming—help me a little—Now ſtep back and be very ceremonious— Where be thoſe Fellowes, who looks out there? Is there ne're a Raſcal She pulls off Hat, Crevat, Garters, and makes as if dreſſing her ſelf. in the way to conduct the Gentlemen in—I find I am like to be finely ſerved among ye, but I ſhall ſet a new face on the houſe e're it be long—how ſneakingly do you ſtand there: but I ſhall make you flye to receive and execute Commands, before I have done.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: This is moſt inſupportable! what beating your Man! hold Sir, what mean you?—

div.stage: Noddy goes to keep Mrs. H. from beating, and ſhe beats him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I begg your pardon—Gentlemen your Servant— Sirrah call your Miſtreſs, tell her I wonder ſhe ſtayes ſo long? Gentlemen you muſt pardon Womens frailties, their decking and trimming themſelves, make 'em often commit ſuch rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: How's this? nay then we are chous'd—and I have ſpent both time and money to a fair end—

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: What a new Lord in the Widows houſe?—would I were fairly off; for I'le lay my life he has ſtruck the Widow in a fair Planet—let me ſee, let me ſee—Venus in Cauda? then 'tis too true, for that's a damn'd Leacherous • lanet.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Sir, Your Servant—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: By my faith you ſhall not ſtir till you have ſeen Iſbel, make haſte and deſire your Miſtreſs to come down—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: She deſires to be excus'd, Sir, the Milliner has brought Gloves to ſhow her—

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: How plain Iſbel? Then I know how the world goes, ay, ay, too true, he has Iſbell d her—a Pox on theſe Widows, there's no truſt in 'em—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: They are gall'd—the Rogues begin to ſneak—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Come, let us ſteal off, and take no notice of him, for he'l jear us to death ſhould we ſtay—Love is not by deſert, but ſuch fluttering half-witted Hectoring Blades are the only taking men with you buxome Widows—come away.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: What, Gentlemen are you for the Wine-Cellar?— Sirrah conduct 'em down, by that time you have drank your Mornings draught Iſbel will be ready—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Spare your Wine Sir, I beſeech you—for ſince the Widow is diſpos'd of—we have no buſineſs here.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: I'le ſee the Wine in a Drunkard's ſhoe firſt, and drink't after he has brew'd it—Hang her, let her go, ſhe's fitted yfaith; a proud domineering young Coxcomb—he'l quickly rattle her bones, and go to Dice with her Money, or at leaſt pick up ſome common Orange-wench, ſet up her Coach, gay Cloaths, teach her to confront his Wife, and laugh Modeſty out of Countenance, or I have no skill in Aſtrology; if he is ſo ſawcy now to call her plain Iſbel, ſhe'l be Bitch and Whore before a Month comes about—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: They have given you the ſlip—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Hang 'em—there are three rubs paſt—and now for the Widow. Thus like a younger Brother I'le begin my fortune, put on impudence, talk wantonly,—and ruffle her luſtily.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: But if ſhe ſhould yield, what then—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Well conſider'd, to prevent that, you muſt ſtep in moſt officiouſly, and interrupt us—but ſhe's coming—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Adieu witty Wife, and I le be ſure to ſtand Centinel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: My life, my Dear!

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I fear I have tired your patience with my long ſtay Sir—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Who wou'd not be devout, and out-wait patience, when ſuch a Heaven is the reward—but Widow, y'are indebted to me—

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: As how, I pray—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I love you Widow; nay, laugh not, for I expect return, or look to your ſelf, for I'm reſolv'd to ſue thee in Cupid's Court, and there I know what decree will paſs—

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: But if I would compound, pray Sir, what will ſatisfie?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: The endleſs enjoying thy ſweet ſelf, Widow, nothing leſs—

sp.speaker: Widd,
sp.p: So by compounding a ſmall Debt I may run into a greater—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Your credit will be the better, there's many a young Blade would give you half the purchaſe to truſt you,— nay, and pay uſe for it.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Some of thoſe roaring Bawdy talking young fellows would be idle, were it for ſuch intereſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Then 'tis a match—Come Widow, ſhort ſervice, a kiſs and to bed, for I am deſperately hungry yfaith—

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Y'are in great haſte, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Troth Widow, I have an excellent ſtomach— and to provoke thine; know, that my kiſſes are Virgins, embraces perfect, ſtrength ſollid, love conſtant, but to come to the point, all extaſie, rapture!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Since you value your ſelf on your honeſty, I'le put you to't Sir,—Will you ſwear you never knew Woman—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: By all that's good, and by thy ſweet ſelf I ſwear, that never as Man I ever yet knew Woman—but if we do not agree, faith Madam, I expect you keep it ſecret, for it may ſpoil my future being; for a ſober man is more ridiculous in this Age, then he was priz'd in the laſt—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How his mein and wit ſurprize me—Well, I find I ſhall love him; for I am very apt to believe what he ſays—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Are you conſidering whether you may believe me or not, Madam—then take altogether—for I add further, that you are the firſt Widow, Maid, or Wife I ever made love to—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: There's ne'r a Jury of young Women in Town that were to view you, but would be inclined to find you guilty— therefore, Sir, I am apt to believe there is ſome ſecret reaſon, and not Devotion keeps you from it—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: None by Heav'n—I kept it in reſerve for thee—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: For Me, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Where can I beſtow it better—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What means this inſolence and rudeneſs, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Fye, Widow, fye, 'tis pleaſing violence, that begets delight.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'le call my Servants, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Do, and I le uſe thee ten times worſe even before witneſs, and then thou art my own Widow—Come, come, dear, ſweet, inticeing Widow, we muſt withdraw—we muſt yfaith, now, now, or never Widow.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Does your Worſhip call?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Pox on you Dog, are you peeping?
Thanks good Tom, thou cameſt in the critical Minute

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But Sir, let us breath a while, what Encouragement have I given you to make you thus confident and forward, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Love, powerful reſiſtleſs Love—you ſee what Mad-men you Women make us—Come, Madam, few words, kind conſent and no Ceremonies are moſt pleaſing—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well, I cannot withſtand, for I begin to grow as impatient as he is, within there who waits?—
If Mr. Gazer and Noddy are below, bring 'em up.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I've loſt my Widow, I fear, there are but two ways that I know, which leads to a Widows bed; they are, Wealth and Impudence—Now if I have took the wrong, how I ſhall curſe my ſelf; here they are, now love if it be thy will.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Gentlemen, y'are welcom, I am now fully reſolved to chooſe one of ye here, let me ſee—but firſt, Mr. Gazer, you are a judicious Aſtrological Perſon, do the Stars ſmile to day? if not, I will defer my choice.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Let me ſee—Oh the beſt time in the world, Madam; for juſt now Mars being Lord of the Aſcendant, is entering into the houſe of Venus—about three Minutes three quarters after Eleven this morning—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That's well—and Mr. Noddy, your judgment of that perſon walking there, what think you of him.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: What I think?—Why I think he's well made, has a aiery mein, I believe he has a pretty Judgment, for his Trimings and Cloaths are not very contemptible—but I believe he's a Whore-maſter, for he has notable waggiſh Eyes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then bear all witneſs, this is the Man whom I have choſe to be my Husband—and ye will infinitely oblige me if you come to my Wedding, and ſo your Servants.

sp.speaker: Nod. Gaz.
sp.p: The Devil go with you—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: I ne'r ſuſpected my Almanack till now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen, I can give you a true invitation and welcom, before 'twas but a flouriſh; but you ſee Fortune will be the bold Adventurers friend—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p:
That I ſhould over-look this damn'd Eclipſe of the
Moon, which was this morning, tho not viſible to us; but I wiſh it may have power here, and by a forked Influence, make him beat her, ſhe Cuckold him, he turn her out of Doors, and with her Eſtate maintain a Whore—

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Amen ſay I,—Sir, your Servant, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: A fair riddance of a brace of Fools.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: But ſee your Brother's come—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I intend to ſet his wit to work.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Sir, this is my Maſter.—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: You ſee, Sir, I have obey'd your Summons ſent me by your man, and now I wou'd know your pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Thus receive your welcom, Sir,—and now I have a requeſt to you.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Name it, Sir, if it conſiſts with honour, and within my power you may conclude it granted Sir—
'Tis for your Siſters ſake I make it.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: You have named the deareſt friend I have, and I can deny nothing is deſir'd in her Name.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: 'Tis this, that you would honour my Wedding, which is to be to Morrow, with ſome ſmall entertainments of your wit—and you are void of all Excuſes; for I have been an ear witneſs of your Siſters frequent commendations of your parts.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: You oblige me with the Injunction; Is it with the Lady of this houſe you Marry, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: The ſame—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Then I muſt recall my promiſe Sir—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Your reaſon,—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Her laſt Husband was an extorting Villain, and has undone our Family, and now enjoys what is mine and my Siſters due.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: But Sir, for her ſake, comply for once—She ſhall not know who you are, but ſhall be obliging to you—and your Siſter too to my knowledg will give you thanks.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: You have prevail'd, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Pray Sir, be pleas'd to walk in, that, I may recommend you to my Wife that muſt be—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: I wait on you, Sir,—Now if I ſhould in my Siſters abſence ſtrike up the Widow—Gad I'le try—and this will be a good opportunity to attempt it.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Madam, I pitty your misfortune, and if there be any thing wherein I can ſerve you, you may command it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You are all obliging, Sir,—My Husband is now below, trying what he can do with his Mother, who is unexpectedly arrived, after being reported to have been dead two years—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: That was a contrivance of my Friend Santloe's, occaſion'd by your Beauty, which had ſuch an Influence over him, that he ventur'd a Fathers Anger to oblige his Paſſion—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Oh friend, Fortune begins once more to ſmile upon my Actions, and has favour'd me in this laſt Enterprize beyond my wiſh—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: As how—Prithee inform us, that we may partake your joys—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Honeſt Sam.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Who helps a lame Dog o're the Stile as well as the beſt.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Put me upon perſwading my Mother to make my Father believe, that my dear Wife here is my Siſter; but the reaſon ſhe knows not—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: And my Miſtreſs, like a kind overjoy'd Mother to ſee her white Boy, moſt readily conſented,—ſo that, Madam, if you at laſt ſhould not be well gifted by Nature, as the reſt of Females are, with Diſſimulation, all our deſigns are ſpoiled, and you muſt trudg to Antwerp agen; for as ſure as death, my old Maſter will turn ye both out of Doors.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: 'Tis an hard task for me, however I'le endeavour, what is't I wou'd not undergo, or ſuffer, for my dear Husband's ſake—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: They are coming—Now Sweet heart carry thy ſelf— bravely now—and let fortune do her worſt—for we are for ever happy.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I'le withdraw—

div.stage: Enter Sir O. Santlow, Lady Santlow.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: And have I thee in my Arms agen? Look ſee, I weep for Joy—had I my Daughter too; but the Dutch Merchant told me the thing I have of their bringing over was a Servant in Antwerp, and not my Child—

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: They cannot deceive me, Sir, let me ſee her, and I ſhall ſoon diſcover their cheat, if it be one—Now heart hold, and let my tongue for once belye thee—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Take courage Love—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Laſs how I tremble!—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: See there, Sweet heart, what a piece of fleſh they have brought me, that is the creature would be my ſuppoſed Daughter; but by Gogmagog, if ſhe is a Cheat, I'le have her ſtript and whipt through every Pariſh, and croſs the Seas till ſhe arrives to her old Kitchin at Antwerp agen.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: Bleſs her Eternal Powers! my life, my comfort, and my nine years grief; but now my joyes, thrice welcom to thy Mothers arms, 'tis ſhe, my Daughter—receive your Child, and thank Heaven for her wonderful reſtoration—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: What, what's this?

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Kind Mother—I ſhall love Diſſimulation for thy ſake, who would not, that heard thee ſwear, conclude this not Counterfeit.—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: My Daughter! it cannot be—no, no, I ſhall ne'r believe it—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Down on your knees—

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: Riſe into my boſom, and receive a Mothers bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Soft Wife, ſoft, have a care how you place your bleſſing; for the Dutch Merchant who came over with you, affirmed, he ſaw her a Servant at an Inn in Antwerp—

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p:
She was ſo, Sir,—I often ſaw her there; but ſeeing ſhe had acquir'd to an honeſt way of living, I would not diſturb her reſt by diſcovering her misfortunes—forgive
me truth, if I abuſe thee with a falſe ſtory, ſince 'tis to preſerve mutual love betwixt an injur'd Father, and beloved Son.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Daughter Clarina! Let me kiſs thee wench—This unexpected joy has forc't tears, and my heart's ſo full with this ſurprize, I know not what to ſay—My joys are now compleat, and this days happineſs has countervail'd all my paſt years of ſorrow for my long loſt deareſt Wife, and Daughter—
Mr. Sanders here, by Gogmagog, the Girl is yours.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: I'm proud of this mighty preſent, Sir, and thus I hug it as Miſers do their Gold.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, I may be once more credited.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Honeſt, honeſt Son, I have wrong'd thy faith; but thou wilt pardon me, I hope; old men are apt to ſuſpect Youth for Wags, that was the reaſon.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Now I may ſecurely venture my head out of my Covert.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Where's Sam: that honeſt merry fellow? I muſt have his pardon too.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Look you Sir, I am very merciful, good natur'd, and prone to forgive; and to ſhow that I have no malice in my heart, if you have another Wife or Daughter to find, and Money to ſpend, I ſhall be very ready to ſerve you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Come hither, Sirrah, let me hugg thee, and take my Curſe from your Knave's Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: For Heav'ns ſake do, Sir, I feel it on my blade here, your Curſe is at leaſt ten Stone weight, and a pound over, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: I'le do thee right Boy, I ne'r knew thee but ſpeak honeſt Engliſh, marry in Dutch, I found thee a knave lately.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: That was only to hold you in play, Sir, till further proofs came over.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: By Gogmagog, I love a harmleſs wit with my life— Well, 'tis my Girl, methinks her Eyes, Noſe and Mouth ſtrangely reſemble her Mothers there—ay, ay, 'tis ſhe, and there's an end; however I'le try further—Wife, Wife, prithee now kiſs me, do I ſay—

Clarina, be obedient, and come and buſs your Father— [Kiſſes her.
Very good, 'tis ſo, now I'le ſwear 'tis ſhe; for they have both the ſame way of kiſſing too; now Wife, ſince I find that my Daughter is my Daughter, I'le proſecute my firſt intention, and this Gentleman ſhall have her for his Wife.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: I am proud of the honour, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Obſerve Wife, obſerve, he is one that handles his Tongue as well as moſt men, a very Genteil Perſon, and as pretty a Spark as e're made love, or kept Miſs, I le ſay that for him—I'le be ſworn by his looks no one wou'd take him for an Eunuch—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: My deſign ſucceeds as I cou'd wiſh—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Nay, I have not forgot my Son too, for I have found a Wife for him, it is the Widow Landwels Neice, the Daughter of old Morley lately dead, her own fortune, it's true, is none of the greateſt; but her Aunt queſtionleſs will give her a ſwingeing Bleſſing when ſhe dies; it is the ſame Maid Eugenia, that was Nurſt with our Clarina; well, it is a pretty creature by Gogmagog, ſhe's a Noſegay of Beauty and ſweet Conditions, how ſay you to't—Boy—ha?—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: The Bleſſing will be greater than I could ever have expected, Sir,—

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: What fortune was this! that I ſhould come ſo opportunely to ſee my happineſs compleated in the Marriage of my two Children.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Well thought on Wife, I had almoſt forgot, we are invited to the Widows Wedding, with a bold brisk young Spark that has clapt her on board yfaith—Do you and your Daughter put on your Hoods and Scarfs, and we'l expect you below in the Parlor; come, Mr. Sanders, come along with me—

div.stage: Manent Peter Santloe, Clarina, La. Santloe, Sam.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Oh Mother, I am ſo tranſported with thoſe new Joys, you kindly have created, I know not which way to begin to pay my Duty.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: But Son, the more I look on her, the more thy Siſter runs in my mind.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Perhaps ſhe's like her, that will carry on the Cheat the better, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: I muſt examine her—of what Countrey and Parentage are you?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Of England, Madam,—and many are the afflictions I have undergone—ſo that my Parentage I have forgot—

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: If it will not renew your ſorrows, give us a ſmall relation of what has paſt.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: So much as my memory will give me leave—for I was not above ſeven years old when my Mother carried me beyond Sea, which was about ten years ſince, with a deſign to put me into a Nunnery; but by the way to Antwerp, we met with Robbers, who ſtript us, convey'd me from my Mother into a Wood; but they having committed ſeveral Outrages, were perſued by Soldiers, ſo they left me, and I wandring about, came at laſt to Antwerp, and was received by the Miſtreſs of an Inn, where I continued a Servant till this Gentleman perſwaded me to come to England.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: Oh my bleſt fortune! my deareſt Child, thrice welcom to my Arms—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: S'life if this ſhould prove his Siſter now—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Look you Mother, my Father's gone—now you may be plain—

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: I am ſorry he is—but l'le haſt to him to confirm what before I only for your ſake averr'd, but did not then know the truth.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: But I hope you are not in earneſt Mother, that it is my Siſter.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: Witneſs Heav'n it is your Siſter—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Hold, hold, good Mother—Kill not your Son— Why I am in love with her Mother, and have made her my Wife.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: But now your love muſt end as to Marriage, and with a Brothers Eyes you muſt look upon her—Come Daughter, let us go down to your Father, who ſhall redouble his joys when he ſhall know the Truth—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Heav'ns! I love him ſo, I cou'd wiſh my ſelf any thing but his Siſter—farewel for ever Love, ſince thus I am deceiv'd in my firſt deſires.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p:
My Siſter, that Northern blaſt has nipt my blooming joys—muſt all my Courtſhip, Expence and Conſtancy,
ay, Conſtancy, Sam. be jilted by the reſurrection of a long loſt Siſter.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A Pox on her, ſay I, ſhe was ever a croſs Brat when ſhe was young, and now ſhe has liv'd in ſpight to croſs your love.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: It cannot be my Siſter—for I find no alteration in me, I am in good temper, and my mind's not ſhook at that dreadful name of Siſter—therefore I am certain there is ſome damn'd riddle in't, which we cannot at preſent expound.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: To make us wiſe enough, Sir, let us to the Widows Wedding, drink briskly, and then with nodding gravity unſold this myſterie if it be one.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Agreed—

lg.l: Tho Love was cruel, Fortune has bin kind,
Since I, a Siſter in a Miſtreſs, find.

div.head: ACT IV, SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sir Gregory Lovemuch, Gazer, Noddy, Noble.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: COme Gentlemen, ſince you are pleas'd to honour me with acting my little Eſſay of fancy, pleaſe you to retire and dreſs, for they are ready to enter.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Worthy Sir, we follow you—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: I ſhall attend you within.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: By Mercury, a neat contrivance, Sir Gregory I applaud your wit.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Tis a profound device, an extravagant fancy, and an inſupportable deſign; and Sir Gregory, I am in an intollerable Conſternation of your Penicranium—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: This will be a brave opportunity to affront her for deceiving us—are all perfect in their parts, Rail and ſpare not, for that is all that we are like to have for our Expences on the Jilting Widow.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: I am ready in mine—

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: And mine is in Capite.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Let us in to dreſs then—Widow, look too't, we'll all your ſcorns repay.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Your Sun of Joys ſhall be Eclips'd to day.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Your Market ſhall be marr'd too, as they ſay—

div.stage: [Exeunt. Enter Sanders, P. Santloe, Clarina, Eugenia.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: But prithee tell me, art thou in earneſt, my Siſter?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: So our ill fate will have it, but ſo much I love, that I cou'd wiſh I were not.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Pox on Kindred—like noble Savage, I wou'd range and chooſe my Miſtreſs where I pleas'd—now muſt ſacred Love be curb'd, and pleaſures loſt, and all long of dull fantaſtick Law.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: We muſt ſubmit, for Reaſon tells us it wou'd be a Sin, ſhould we purſue our Love—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Friend, I can but pitty thy misfortunes in loſing of a Miſtreſs, but muſt congratulate your Joyes in finding of a Siſter. Now, fair Eugenia, ſhall I at laſt receive the fair reward for all my Conſtancy? ſpeak kindly, and return my love with yours—and then I'm happy—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Faith Madam, yield—do not caſt away a handſom proper man, for ſo ſmall a toy; my Siſter here has bin more kind to me, than hitherto you have prov'd to him—

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: My Aunts to rule my fate, and I muſt chooſe a Husband with her liking, I'le make it known to her, and if ſhe approves of it, Heav'n knows, I can enjoy no greater happineſs— for without bluſhing, I confeſs, I love—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Oh my kind Saint!

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Sanders, to your Poſt, ſee where they come—But do'ſt hear, prithee do not make love to her, for by Heav'n, tho ſhe's my Siſter, I ſhall grow wondrous Jealous, and conſequently quarrelſom.

div.stage: [Sand. goes to Cla. P. S. to Eug.—
Enter the Widow as Married to Mrs. Hadland, Sir O. Santloe, Lady Santloe, Mr. Hadland as a Servingman, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come my long wiſht for Lady, your happy return is a ſecond feaſt to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Ye'are all moſt freely welcom—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: We thank you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: But is my Brother, do you ſay, ſo much in love with my Widow?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: I overheard him but now complaining on his deſtiny that ſhould make him ſo deſperately in love with your Enemy, that I thought he would have rebelled againſt himſelf, there's ſuch a mighty feud between the two old Enemies in his Breaſt, Love and Honour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Laſs poor man—I wiſh he had my place to day, he is abler than I to perform the duty that belongs to a young Widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, pray ſit—that worthy friend of yours, Madam, is pleaſed to entertain us for a while, and now I ſuppoſe they are ready to enter—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Madam, here you may before-hand read the Argument of what I do deſign—Now Love, prove but ſo kind to inſpire her with an equal ſlame, make her a true Widow, and my young Spark I ſhall ſoon graſt on your Stock—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha, what's here? a Letter inclos'd, this muſt be conceal'd till a fitter time to be read— [Aſide. We are oblig'd to you, for this Nights diverſion, and ſhall ſtudy a requital—If my young Blade here proves a faſhionable keeping Husband, this Gentleman, if his Letter ſpeaks of love, ſhall not long languiſh, nor deſpair—for I like him ſtrangely— [Aſide. See here, Sir, the Argument is pretty—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Good, ſhe has convey'd the Letter as I cou'd wiſh, now half my toyle is over—Madam, they are Entering—

div.stage: Then a thing like a Globe Aſcends, Sir Gregory Lovemuch ſitting on it, in an habit repreſenting fire—On each ſide the Stage, aſcends Noddy, repreſenting Water, and One repreſenting Earth—Gazer Deſcends, who repreſents Air—Noble goes behind Sir Gregory Lovemuch—to promp him.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: The flame of Zeal—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.l: —The wicked fire of Luſt
Does now ſpread heat through Water, Air, and Duſt.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Ha! He's out at the beginning—The wheel of Time

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: The Devil ſet fire on the Diſtaffe—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: What a Devil means all this?—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I, that was wont in elder time to paſs
For a bright Angel, now am made an Aſs,
And ſo corrupted with the upſtart fires
Of hated Avarice and hot deſires,
Which in unlawful ſheets were kindled firſt
By forward Girls, falſe Wives, and Widows luſt.
That I, even Fire, who pureſt Gold did try,
From theſe baſe heats, my ſelf can't purifie;
I once was reverenc't, Charity did thaw,
And did keep up the Hoſpitable Law,
But ſtead of me, a Baſtard heat now burns,
And to ſupply my Landlord's luſt, it turns.
Now Matron Widow's Leachery ſo great
They ne'r conſult their years, but luſtful heat
And wed young Fops that may perform the feat.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Heart! Who ſhould this be?—Some Rogue— but I'le let'em take their ſwing—and afterwards will be fully Reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Upon my word, Monſieur Fire is a notable hot Satirical Blade—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
