sp.p: What ſhould my Brother mean to rail ſo—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: After this hear, you Ladies fat and fair,
Open your Caſements wide, and take in Air;
But not that Air, falſe Women make up Oaths with,
No, nor that Air Gallants perfume their Cloaths with;
I am that Air that keeps about the Clouds,
None of my Kindred were ſmelt out in Crouds;
Yet ſome there are that are my Chief Polluters,
Widows that falſifie their faiths to Suiters,
And will give fair words, when the Sign's in Cancer,
But at the next remove a ſcurvy Anſwer;
Come to the poor mens Houſes, Eat their Banquet
With ſmock-fac't Boy, at Night be toſt in Blanket.
He that believes a Widows word ſhall fail,
When Venus Gown-skirt ſweeps the Dragon's Tail;
Fair weather the firſt day ſhe makes to any,
The ſecond Clowdy, and the third day Rainy;
The fourth day a great Storm, Lightning and Thunder,
A Bolt ſtrikes the Suiter, a Boy keeps her under.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo, ſome Raſcal's crept in on purpoſe to diſgrace me; but I'm reſolv'd they ſhall ſhare in my diſgrace—

sp.speaker: Sir O. S.
sp.p: By Gog Magog, a notable ſharp Air this, Madam—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: He has perfumed the Room well—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A man may ſmell her meaning two Rooms off, tho his Noſe wanted reparations—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Prithee ſtep out, and knovv vvhat his meaning is, is this the Entertainment I promiſed to my ſelf?—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: His love ſure has made him mad—but I'le go know the Cauſe—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.l: Now Gentiles all, ſince fire has made ye hot,
Come bath in me, for I'm a Water-pot:
Water's my Name, I come your Pipes to fill
Without the Charge of Water-houſe, or Mill—
But firſt, I will a Widows Cheeks beſprinkle,
Which glow with heat, her leacherous Eyes do twinkle.
And I'le endeavour too, to lay the duſt
Of Widows hot deſires, and boundleſs luſt,
Then will diſplay her ſhame—From ſuch as ſhe
I firſt took weakneſs and inconſtancy;
I ſometimes ſwell above my banks, and ſpeed,
Widows are oft with Child before they Wed.
Where I'm leaſt ſeen, there my moſt danger lyes;
So in thoſe Parts hid moſt from humane Eyes:
He heart, her love, or what may be more cloſe.
I know no Mercy, ſhe thinks that no loſs
In her poor Gallants, Pyrates thrive in me,
I help to Caſt away, and ſo does ſhe—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.l: Curſe on his Wit—I am all confuſion—

sp.speaker: A Man.
sp.l: Earth ſtands for a full point, me ye ſhou'd hire
To ſtop the gaps of Water, Air, and Fire
Your Husband lov'd me, he lock't me in his Cheſt,
I was the only Idol of his Breaſt.
Now he is dead—
He ſhall have Gold, enough to glut his Soul,
And as for Earth, I'le ſtop his Cranes throat full.
With eaſe a Miſer's appetite we pleaſe,
But Luſt in Widows, is a damn'd Diſeaſe.
And proves the moſt inſatiate avarice.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.l: And now to vex you, Widow, to your face,
See, once four warning Elements, embrace.

div.stage: Thunder and Lightning.—Enter five or ſix like Devils; Water and Earth are let down to the middle with two Devils—Fire and Air, are carried up half way into the Air, with two Devils—

sp.speaker: Sir G. Gaz. Noddy.
sp.p: Help, help, help; Murder—Murder—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Widow, for Heav'ns ſake, intercede for us to the Devils—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Oh law, what will my Mother and Siſter ſay, when they hear I am carried away by the Devil—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Who are ye, diſcover your ſelves then?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: By Charles's Wain, don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Why look you, d'ye ſee, it is I, it is I—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
My old Suiters, we are all oblig'd to you, my Maſters, you have taken great pains to make your ſelves Ridiculous—
—ha,—ha,—Pray Sir releaſe 'em for my ſake—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: You may Command, Madam, let 'em down there—

sp.speaker: All Suit.
sp.p: Thanks good Widow.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Whe faith ſince we were to loſe you, Madam, we thought loſers might have leave to ſpeak, and therefore by offering our Service to this Gentleman, we got this opportunity to ſpeak a little of our minds to you—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: And I think we have pretty freely, and at our own Coſts too; for I owe Money for ſome of the Painting—but the Planets are ſufficient to pay the Painter—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: If ever I court Widow again for your ſake, may I be made a Piſſing-poſt of; well, I find Widows are confounded inſupportable witty Devils.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: We are all oblig'd to you, Sir, for this diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: My ſhame, Madam, urg'd me to contrive ſome way to diſcover the Authors of my diſgrace—But, Madam, to divert you I have brought a Servant of mine to entertain you with a Dance—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I am indebted to you for this favour, Sir—Pleaſe Gentlemen to walk in and partake of a ſmall Collation, and then, my Dear, we will retire to ſurfeit on Loves ſweets—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We follow you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Curſe on ill luck! What a Devil ſhould be become of this Siſter of mine, had ſhe not promiſed to get the Widow for me, I had not ſlipt the opportunity which now is irrecoverably loſt, ſhe's Married! now the Pox or Impotence be his Curſe, for I cannot with patience ſee my ſelf thus chous't— ha—here comes my brisk Bridegroom—good, I have thought on an excellent way, if poſſible, to retrieve her— I'le wheadle him to drink, make him damnably drunk, ſo conſequently impotent, and a Widow diſappointed, turns Devil, will ſue a divorce, and then ſhe's mine.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Oh Sir, moſt opportunely met—are you alone?—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,—Your Pleaſure—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I am come to—cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: How Sir!—cut my Throat, you'l give me a reaſon, Sir, for it, I hope—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I ſaw what amorous glances paſt between my Wife and you at Dinner, and ſince too I have diſcovered that which has rais'd ſuch a Storm within me, that nothing but thy death can reſtore my former calmneſs—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Jealous by this light—I hope he has not met with my Letter I convey'd to the Widow— [Aſide. Heav'ns Sir, what jealous on the firſt night!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I am all rage with jealouſie, your Letter, Sir— ſee there the reaſon, Villain, and then judg if I can pardon ſuch an injury—Therefore prepare to yield up either Life, or Love—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, ſince you have diſcovered my paſſion, then know I do, muſt, and will love your Widow, nay, dote upon the ſight of her, and yet no harm to you, ſince you poſſeſs the wealth, you cannot barr a longing ſtander by, to wiſh and ſigh, ſince you know 'tis in vain; therefore I will perſiſt— ah 'tis a charming Creature!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Hell and Furies! ſhall I ſtand tamely ſtill, and hear a fellow boldly to my face proclaim my Infamy!

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: A fellow, Sir▪ Provoke me not, I ſay provoke me not; if you do, by Heav'n, if poſſible, I'le cuckol'd thee before thy face—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: This is beyond all patience, baſe Villain draw—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Piſh Sir, your little Bodkin frights not me, ſee I have one can match it—Yet I believe thee Valiant, or ſuch a little whipper-ginnie durſt not have been ſo deſperate to have ventur'd on a longing Widow—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: How, Sir, have at thy heart!—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Good Child, thou art too forward,—reſerve thy vigour for another place, it will be little enough, I'le engage— for young, Sir, there can be no compariſon between you and I, in love affairs—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: How mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: You may perhaps be well enough for the Theory, to cringe, and whine, and wheadle your ſelf into a Virgins heart; but a Widows wiſe diſcerning Eye muſt of neceſſity read here the only man that's fitteſt for the Practick part—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Heav'ns! Do but hereafter look upon her with one pleaſing glance, and I'le damn thy Soul.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: A Bully in Swadling-clouts by this light, 'tis the youngeſt Hector I ever met with in my life—a gad, little Squire, were ſhe the great Turk's favourite, I'de look and gaze altho I knew my death ſhould follow, and let me tell thee, had ſomebody been true to their promiſe, your fortune had been mine—therefore, little one, you may thank my croſs Stars for your good ſucceſs. A Pox on an abſent Siſter—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: How Sir, oblig'd to you? Oh inſupportable! thou baſe detracter of my honour, who not only would ſupplant my love, but blaſt my reputation, and make me undeſerving of a Ladies favour.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: If you come to that point, Sir, what can you boaſt of, ſhould be ſo attractive? I muſt confeſs thou appeareſt a hopeful Stripling, and I queſtion not you have the pretty impertinents of one of your Age, as Dancing, Singing, affected Geſtures, be peirtly witty, making bold with every new Play comes out, and extravagantly tawdrey in every new faſhion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Death and the Devil!

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Theſe accompliſhments, I muſt confeſs, may be very ſurprizing to a poor young thing of a Boarding-School, who never had love made to her but by her Dancing-Maſter, or ſome ſuch follow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: This is beyond all ſufferance—

div.stage: [Strives to run at him, he Parryes.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p:
This won't do—and now, little one, I le diſcharge my Conſcience, between you and I, I do verily believe, the Widow that was, and your Wife that is, Married you only for a Drudg or Steward of her Eſtate, while ſhe ſpends it on pleaſures, with ſuch vigorous Blades as my ſelf, and who knows it may be my turn; which if it be, faith
I'le be very reaſonable, and Cuckold thee as ſeldom as poſſibly I can—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I'le hear no more; but thus will make a paſſage to thy Soul, for I ſwear thy Ruine, Death, Damnation—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Say you ſo, then 'tis time to look about—and ſince you provide me, little one, know this, that if I kill thee, I ſwear to marry the Widow the next day—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Thus I prevent thy boaſting— dull, dull, Brother, not know your own fleſh and blood. Nob. makes up to her with his Sword, Mrs. H. diſcovers her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: My Siſter▪ I'm all amazement▪

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Now Sir, what think you of my deſign?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Deſign quotha! 'twas well you diſcovered your ſelf, or I had ſpoil'd all;—but I'm a Dog if I underſtand what you mean?—you are Married—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I am to the Widow, I knew not how to cheat the Parſon; but I queſtion not, but to deceive the Widow e're I ſleep—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: As how, as how?—I long to hear—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: See, my Husband comes with ſome intelligence—.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Is that my Brother Hadland?—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Sir, My Lady is retir'd to her Chamber—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Leave off your diſtance now, ſweet heart; for I have told my Brother all.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Kind-Brother I obliging Siſter!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: But Brother, do you like my Widow in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Like her! Heavn's! I love her infinitely! were ſhe not Miſtreſs of a farthing, agad, I believe I ſhould have Married her, there's ſuch an aiery ſweetneſs in her face—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Say you ſo, then along with me, I have one deſign more, and if that take, we are once more happy—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Lead on whil'ſt I follow, and admire thy wit.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: T Thus far I am proſperous, Widow, I have not done with you yet; I have wheadled all her Keys out of her Cuſtody, and in her Cloſet I found the Writing of my Eſtate, thou dear, dear Parchment, how I am over-joy'd to hug thee in my Arms once more—the Widow comes—

div.stage: Enter Widow, undreſs'd in a Night-Gown.
div.p: My life, my Soul, my only joys on Earth, haſte, haſte to Bed, that I may be compleatly bleſs'd with an Heav'n of Pleaſures and delight.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh let me embrace the mighty Treaſure I have this day gain'd!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Delay not the Conſummation of our bliſs, to bed, to bed, my dear, and there we'l ſurfeit with delights unſpeakable.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I go, but prithee ſtay not long behind—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I'le but to my appartment, and undreſs, then fly to rifle all thy Charms—now, Widow, thou art ſafe—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Kind Rogue, I am—I cannot avoid laughing to think how ſurpriz'd the Widow will be, well Girl, I'le endeavour to behave my ſelf ſo, that ſhe ſhall have no reaſon to complain, nor you to repent the trick you have put upon her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Do that, and I am well pleas'd, I believe I am the firſt Bridegroom that ever procur'd for his Bride the firſt Night.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: The obliging'ſt in the world, and the kindeſt Siſter too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Away then—be brisk, and diſgrace me not.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Dear, honeſt, kind, obliging, witty Rogue, adieu—now for the Widow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.l: Widow, y'are caught at laſt—
Thy Husband's ſubtleties ſhall be repaid,
Thus Women are by Women beſt betray'd.

div.head: SCENE the Second. The Hall.
div.stage: Sir O. Santloe, Sanders, Gazer, Noddy—Sam. Drinking at a Table.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Well done, my friends, put it briskly about— now the Bride and Bridegroom are preparing for bed, let us Drink their healths—Sam. give me a Glaſs—Son Sanders, top and bottom to you—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: I'le do you reaſon, Sir—Mr. Santloe, the Bride and Bridegrooms healths.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Mr. Gazer—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: I'le Pledg you, Sir, tho by Aries the Sign is in the Head with me already, Mr. Noddy have at you—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let it come, hang Sorrow, it muſt be drown'd, I find—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Sir, I'le not bate you an ace of top and bottom, off with it, off with it for ſhame, I ſay again, top and bottom is my word—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Lay aſide Indignation, Sir, I'le do't, tho I dye for't, but yfeck I have ſo topt and bottom'd it already, I can hardly breath—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Hye, that's he, that's he—What, Son Peter, no frollick, no frollick, Sirrah Boy, be merry, or I'le diſ-inherit thee—Ah, when I was of your Age, and at the Temple, I was the Cock of all the Jovial Blades in Town—I was always the Captain of a Temple-Rebellion, broke Benchers heads with the Temple pots moſt dexterouſly, lye with my Laundreſs, got her with Baſtard, and made her lay it at a Benchen's door, by Gogmagog—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: So, ſo, all will out—now ſhall I have pious inſtructions to follow the Example of a ſober Father—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: I have beat Watches, have had my head broke, and been in the Compter ſo often, that it coſt your Grandfather above a Hundred pounds one year to cure my broken head, and to ranſom me from Limbo—and yet you ſee, Sirrah, I am a ſober diſcreet man now—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Wondrous diſcreet thus to diſplay your weakneſs—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Son Sanders, what ne'r a Song in Budget—by Gogmagog, this whoring Age has ſpoil'd all good harmleſs mirth and Company—All the young fellows now a days ſingle out their Does, and retire as if it were nothing but rutting time with 'em—but in my Days we ſhould not have ſat half ſo long without a Catch or two, and top and bottom going briskly about yfaith—

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Prithee let's have the Song, you made the laſt drinking bout, and one glaſs more will lay your Father to reſt—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: I have a Song, Sir, which if you pleaſe well ſing— but all muſt joyn in the Chorus.—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Yes marry ſhall they, Sir—and ſo will I—but firſt let every one take top and bottom in his hand—

lg.l: COme troul it away,
We'll drink up the day,
Let none from his ſtanding retire,
We'l Laugh, Drink, and Sing,
And Bacchus's Spring
We'l drain, and our proweſs admire.
Cho. We'l Laugh, &c.
Old Age we deſpiſe
Whilſt Wine we can prize,
And briskly can take off our Glaſſes;
Wine, life does repair,
And baniſhes Care,
But Temp'rance wou'd make us all Aſſes.
Cho. Wine, life, &c.
Let the Pollitick fool
Live dully by Rule,
While our Wits we refine in our Liquor,
My Soul's in that Wine
Which puts the Divine
To a Nonplus, and turns up the Viccar.
Cho. My Soul's, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Well done yfaith my Lads—and now off with top and bottom— [All Drink. ho, ho, ho Boys, Peter I'le give thee an Hundred pounds a year more for this Boy—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Say, and hold Sir, that you have often done in your Glaſſes; but has forbid the banes when ſober—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Oh the ſweet days of Youth—I have roar'd it in my time yfaith—and ſo topt and bottom'd it, that by Gogmagog we have all bin top heavy before we have parted— Now Son Peter, ne'r a Jig or Horn-pipe about you? how has my Money bin ſpent at Dancing-School, I pray?—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: He would make me as ridiculous as himſelf— [Aſide. Thoſe Dances are quite out of faſhion, Sir, and Genteiler are now in Mode, Sarabands, Minuets Entries, and the like—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Pox on your hard nam'd Dances and Wine too, they never prove good, nor wholſom—but Sirrah, to convince you, nothing can be finer than a Lancaſhire Horn-pipe— Fidlers ſtrike up—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: I Vow, Sir, 'tis in ſupportably admirable—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Before I left the Temple, I was the only Reveller as old as I was; I cou'd have footed the Meaſures, and Danc't Horn-pipes with e're a young fellow of 'em all. Sam, Give me top and bottom—Mr. Noddy, my Service to you—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Yfeck I'le pledg you—

lg.l: Is not John Sanders dead?[Sir O. Sings.
And is not his Wife a Whore?
For ſhe will go drunk to bed,
And yet ſhe'l have one Pot more?
Our Cat is to be hang'd,
And all to be tumbl'd i'th' mire,
For ſcratching my Wifes Huquiſſin,
As ſhe ſat by the Fire.—

div.p: Ah, when I was young, I had a thouſand ſuch frollicks as theſe, off with your Liquor man, off with it, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Top and bottom, as you ſay, Sir Oliver, yfecks—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: So ho, my Boys, who ſays I am old, ſee there my conqueſt over Youth—this Whoring weakens 'em ſo, they are not able to take of a chirping Cup or two now adays—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Now Sam, thy frollick?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What grinding of Knives Sir? have at it then— Knives to Grind, Knives to Grind—

div.stage: Takes off his Perriwig, and runs a Chair before him, like a Wheel-barrow.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: How now Sam, what art thou frollicking too—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A Well-willer to mirth Sir, and now you ſhall ſee me grind Knives as dexterouſly with a Chair, as the Fellows in the Street with a Grind-ſtone—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Well done my Lad—Here's ſomething to encourage thee—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What's here, a Newgate Groat, by this Light he's ſhort lived, he is ſo confounded liberal—ah Sir, this is nothing; I can tumble with any Bartholomew Fellow, Run up a Wall like a Cat; but I can act a Breaſt of Mutton ſo naturally, that our Cook-Maid the other night had like to have ſpitted me for one, I did it ſo to the life—

div.stage: Enter Sir Gregory Lovemuch, beaten in by a Maid with a Spit—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, Murder, Murder—

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Out you old Leacher, invade my Honour?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Laugh.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Wats the matter, Sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p:
I only deſir'd a kindneſs or ſo, being ſet agog with
the Widows Marriage, and the Baggage had not only the incivility to deny me; but has moſt unmercifully chaſtis'd me too.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: By Gogmagog well enough ſerved, for leaving top and bottom—and old Letchery will be catteryauling, tho they are ſure to come by the worſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: For Heav'ns ſake, Gentlemen, come to the Bride-Chamber, ſome accident or other has hapned; for the Bride cryes out, and ſeems by her Speech to be in ſome ſtrange confuſion.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: It's nothing but her being coy, and yfaith the young Bridegroom ſeems a man of Mettle, and will put her to't, I'le warrant.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What ſhould this mean?

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Let us go ſee, I fear my young Blade's too brisk for her—gently, gently good Youngſter, be not ſo boyſterous— [Shreiks again. Again, what a ſtubborn Baggage 'tis—on my liſe he is raviſhing her—let us in and ſee Gentlemen—

div.head: SCENE the Laſt.
The Widow diſcovered ſitting on a Bed in a Night-Gown, Noble in Bed, holding her by the Gown.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Heav'n protect me! Villain unhand me—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: I ſay, Widow come to Bed, or I ſhall grow very angry; for I'm impatient, and will not be delay'd any longer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Guard me, ye Powers above! Protect my honour, or I'm loſt for ever ſhould my Husband come—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p:
Whoſe fault will that be; therefore be ſpeedy, let me antedate my young Squire, and I'le be gone— Nay, no ſtruggling, but yield quietly—I need not a reſiſtance, for I am all on flame already—not yet? agad perſiſt in ſtubbornneſs, and I'le publiſh it in all places that I have layn
with thee, no matter whether it be truth or no—and then Lady bright, that trifling title Honour, muſt be ſurrender'd; but be kind, and I ſhall be all ſilence and obedience—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'le rather dye, than yield—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Say you ſo? Then I find I muſt try ſtrength.

div.stage: They ſtrive, ſhe gets from him—is going out of the Door. Enter Mrs. Hadland meets her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha! my Husband!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: What coming for me Widow? This was kindly done—let us to Bed, for now I am ready to perform the Rites of Love.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What ſhall I do? undone, for ever wretched—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: What means this ſtrange Confuſion!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Alaſs, Sir, I'm not well—I was juſt going to call up my Maid, for ſome Cordial—Tis but too true, for my Spirits fail me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Such vain excuſes belong to Virgin Modeſty, but Widows ſhould know better—then, lay aſide this veil, and meet my love with equal flames, that both may be tranſported into Extaſies—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: For ever I am ruin'd—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Sure y'are the firſt Widow ever fear'd th' imbraces of a ſecond Husband—Come, come tremble not—but to Bed.

div.stage: [Leads her to the Bed, opens the Curtain, diſcovers Noble ſtanding in a Night-Gown upon the Bed—
div.p: Ha! Noble here—Hell and the Devil!
Baſe perfidious Woman, now I ſee the cauſe of your diſorders, was your Luſt ſo hot you could not ſtay till the firſt Night was paſt?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Good Sir, hear me—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: May'ſt thou be for ever dumb, or I deaf, rather than lend an Ear to thy bewitching tongue—Now Sir, how durſt you attempt the diſhonouring of my Bed? Do you laugh? I ſhall ſpoil your mirth—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Who can forbear at ſuch an Idle queſtion—rather Sir, how durſt you Marry, and fondly think to preſerve ſuch a tempting Creature entirely for your ſelf,—Sir, where I love, I dare do any thing to enjoy; and a Pox on your officious haſt and jealouſie, had you but ſtayed two minutes longer, your buſineſs had been done, and you ne'r the wiſer—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Confuſion! This to my face?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Yes, faith Sir, 'twas moſt uncivilly done, and very unlike a Husband to intrude; but I pardon you for once, for I hope in time you will underſtand better—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Baſe Villain! Did I for this caſt a friends Arms about thee? gave thee the welcom of a man of Honour? and is this your return of gratitude? Hence, begon, and take that Volume of corrupted Beauty; for henceforth ſheſh I be to me like the Book of Fate, for ever claſpt.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Wretched Woman, was this the promis'd bleſſing of an indulgent Husband! Speak Sir, and clear my Honour, how you got here; for Heav'n be my Witneſs, I was as great a ſtranger to his being here, as you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: In vain are idle words, out of my doors, for ever I diſcard you from my houſe—

sp.speaker: Wid.
Mrs. H.
sp.p: I thank you for my own, ſweet Lady—but I ſcorn to be out done in courteſie—therefore in return, make you this preſent—provided you'l confirm you Eſtate on me—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I will—what laugh you at my miſery—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Faith Widow, you are caught; for know, I am already Married to another—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How Married to another! I am all aſtoniſhment: Villain, how durſt you attempt ſo deſperate an act; an act by which your life is forfeited? and queſtion not, but I'le have full revenge for this affront y'ave offer'd me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Rail on, 'tis Muſick in my Ears, but faith you are not like to ſtir till we are friends—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What's your deſign? who are you—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p:
Come, come, no more queſtions, my deſign was
only to provide a Husband for thee—how ſay you to my Friend here, methinks he would make an able Husband for a Widow.

sp.speaker: Within. Sir O.
sp.p: So ho, Mr. Bridegroom open the Door, and let Sack-poſſet enter—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: How ſay you, Widow, is it a match—or they all enter, and I'le forſwear all I have ſaid, and make you infamous to the world—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: And faith ſo will I, Widow—if you conſent not.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hold, hold Gentlemen—What ſhall I do? my Honour this way will be loſt—Leave me to my own choice, you know not what then I may do—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: All one for that, Widow, ſo it muſt be—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Or Egad they come—ſee I am ready to unlock, is it a Bargain?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Take half my Eſtate, my Houſe, Goods, any thing, rather than force me to ſo raſh an Act—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: How raſh! to Marry an able fellow! this is an affront, I cannot put up; therefore thus I revenge my ſelf—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hold, hold Sir, let me conſider but one Minute—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: I'le give thee a looking and a thinking time, that is but fair; for I am certain the more you view me and conſider, the more you'l like me—

sp.speaker: Within. Sir O.
sp.p: On my Conſcience they are reconcil'd, done their buſineſs, and fairly turn'd to ſleep.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Now, Madam, what is it you reſolve?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Not to conſent—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Egad they come then—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hold, what are you?—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: No queſtions, for Conſcience ſake—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I yield, I yield—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Swear then—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By all that's good, I will be yours—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Seal it—

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Gentlemen, pray enter—

div.stage: Enter Sir O. Santloe, P. Santloe, Mr. Sanders, Lady Santloe, Clarina, Eugenia, Sir G. Lovemuch, Gazer, Noddy, Attendants. Mr. Hadland without Diſguiſe—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: What's here, two Bridegrooms? I'le warrant her crying out, was, for want of the Second—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Gentlemen, bear witneſs, I here diſcharge the Widow, from her Marriage with me.—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: How, parting before ye have bedded? what's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Some private Reaſons, Sir Oliver, which more at leiſure you ſhall know—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Before theſe Gentlemen, I take him for my Husband.

sp.speaker: Sir G. L. Gaz. Noddy.
sp.p: The Devil give you Joy then—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: See here the transformation—and Widow in a young huffing Bully, ſee your Friend and Servant Eliz. Hadland—

div.stage: Mrs. H. and her Husband diſcover themſelves.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: And Thomas Hadland, her Serving-man and Husband.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Am I out-witted by my Enemy then!

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: What a notable frollicking Woman is this! Is ſhe the Bridegroom, and my worſhipful Serving-man, are you there?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: A poor wrong'd Gentleman, Sir, willing to ſerve for his own—

sp.speaker: Sir G. L.
sp.p: Pox on her, was it ſhe diſgrac'd me at the Treat, I'le ſteal off before they take notice of me—

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: By Capricorn, and ſo will I—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, d'ye ſee, I have ſpent at leaſt Forty Pounds in Cloaths, Coaches, Journeys and ſo forth, in Courting of you, and ſince you have chous'd me of your ſelf, I expect ſatisfaction—which I will have if there be Law—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Take your courſe, Sir—

sp.speaker: Noddy.
sp.p: So I will, by Jehoſaphat—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Now Madam, no more your Enemy, but Siſter; for I muſt call this Gentleman Brother.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Then my fortune's better than I could have expected,
ſince I am aſſured he is a Gentleman in all reſpects—and thus all animoſities ſhall ceaſe.—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
P. S.
sp.p: 'Slid Sam, what's to be done now.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Your Friend and Servant knows no more than the poſt, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: How ſay you, Madam, is it a match between your Neice and my Son? do't, and I am reſolv'd Mr. Sanders ſhall be my Son in Law—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I freely conſent, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Mrs. Eugenia, your hand—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But not my heart, for that is Mr. Sanders's—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But with your leave, Sir Oliver, I'le joyn 'em—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: With all my heart, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Mr. Sanders, take this Lady.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, bleſt be your goodneſs for this ineſtimable treaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Cuds boddykins, what means ſhe?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Here Mr. Santloe, in a Siſter find a wiſe—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Sure the Widow has dealt with the Devil, or elſe hath heard of our mutual love, and thus ſooths our paſſions—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: By Gogmagog, the Widow's mad—my Son Marry his own Siſter! what Riddle is this?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: One of Seventeen years ſtanding, Sir—You remember my Siſter Morly Nurs'd your Daughter, who at that time had a Daughter too—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: What of all this—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: My Siſters fortunes decaying, ſhe gave you her Eugenia, and kept your Clarina with her ſelf—afterwards fortune ſmiling on her Husband's induſtry, ſhe on her Death-bed did reveal this ſecret, and wiſht me when occaſion ſerved to make it known—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Hyeday the Town's our own agen—

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, this is beyond all preſident, not to be equal'd—and now Sir, I may with confidence own I was this day Married to my ſuppoſed Siſter.

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: By Gogmagog, you were a deſperate Boy; how could you tell but that it was your Siſter in earneſt?

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.p: Nature was not ſo dull to let me languiſh for a Siſter; for notwithſtanding what my Mother ſaid, yet love retain'd its native heat, and bad me ſtill love on—Oh my bleſt Soul—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Daughter come into thy Father's arms, ſee, exceſs of Joy will make affection melt.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: What tears have I beſtow'd on a loſt Daughter, yet left her behind me.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: This is beyond all thought ſurprizing—and now, Girl, ſince your wit has been the kind directer of my Fortunes, with my Widows leave here, freely command whatever's in my power—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I ſhall comply with you in everything.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I thank you for your obliging offer, and I ſhall deſire nothing more, but the confirmation of that Portion which your rigorous Husband had deceiv'd my Father of, before he dyed—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your generoſity is ſo great I can deny you nothing— conſult with your Lawyer, and I ſhall willingly ſubſcribe to any thing you ſhall deſire—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H. Mr. H.
sp.p: We are oblig'd to you—

sp.speaker: Sir O.
sp.p: Cudsboddy kins, this was a notable waggiſh trick, and by Gogmagog, much like a ſecond Wedding, and I give you joy with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: Madam, fear nothing; tho I have appear'd a wild Debauchee; yet you ſhall find an Indulgent Husband—and now, Gentlemen, let us in and congratulate each others good ſucceſs and fortunes.

lg.l: Thus in the Storms of Fortune you may find,
Where Juſtice is deficient, Wit proves kind.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: KNowing too well, Gallants, your natural ſpight,
We bar your cenſuring priviledg to Night;
For your Diverſion, this was ne'r deſign'd,
How can our Author then, expect you kind?
Your malice is ſo great to One unknown
That like the Play, or not, you cry him down,
Who is not one o'th' huffing Wits o'th' Town:
Nay, your ill natures bare ſo great a ſway,
Often ye Damn, befor you've ſeen the Play;
Such Bully-Wits, like Butchers ſhould not ſit,
There's ſuch a Native Cruelty in them,
Without a Conſultation they condemn.
Then to Vacation-Cuſtomers we ſue,
We have our ends to Night, if we've pleas'd you;
Kind Sirs, let not the Criticks of the Town
Awe ye—But let your Judgments be your Own,
Conſider well—
Here is no Satire on a Marry'd life,
No Cheats diſcover'd of the Man of Trade,
Nor who Gallants your Wives are here diſplay'd,
Nor your own ſecret Pleaſures too betray'd:
Then Judg the Play, unbyaſs'd may ye be,
And from the ſnarling Criticks ſet us free.
